title: YIKES - The Worlds Most Powerful Smart Phone...
description:
ROG has done it again! Get Unlimited everything for just 29 bucks with Tello HERE: https://bit.ly/tellojre Huge thanks to Tello for sponsoring this video. Most smartphones survive my durability test. However - Last year's ROG phone 5 failed pretty bad. I hoped that this years ROG 6 Pro would survive. But it looks like if you do nothing to fix the problem - you get the same results. The ROG phone 6 pro fails my durability test. The worlds most powerful smartphone - is among the weakest built smartphones on the planet. 

Watch the ROG 6 pro teardown here: https://youtu.be/9O-cYMtFG5c

Get my Shirts and Razor Knife here! https://www.jerryrigknife.com/ 

Anker is named as the Official Charging Partner of JerryRigEverything: http://ankerfast.club/JREpartnership 

*Follow me for updates!*
Instagram: http://instagram.com/zacksjerryrig
Facebook: http://on.fb.me/1U4bQqv
Twitter: https://twitter.com/ZacksJerryRig

LARGE tool kit: http://amzn.to/2DURcr7
Travel Tool Kit: https://amzn.to/30LKXOY
Mega Tool Kit: https://amzn.to/2OwequL
Plastic Pry tools: http://amzn.to/1Tu57pI
Metal phone opening tool: http://amzn.to/1WdOFv0
Replacement phone parts: https://www.fixez.com/?utm_source=JerryRigEverything&utm_medium=homepage&utm_campaign=JerryRigEverything

The camera I used to film this video: http://amzn.to/2p7GtkX (GH6 https://amzn.to/3LyfW8d)
The Lens I used for this video: http://amzn.to/1QOXDw2
Wide angle lens: http://amzn.to/2qiYM4u
And this Metabones adapter: http://amzn.to/2iZ67Ty
This is the drone I use: https://click.dji.com/AI2tmSb0onM9XPVwb-Se0g

TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page': https://www.youtube.com/user/JerryRigEverything/about

JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: Today we're going to be durability testing this $1300 ROG Phone 6 Pro. I think it was released last week...last month? One second. I'm losing track of time. There it is....July. So maybe I'm a little bit late. I gotta get back on schedule. But, it was still released this year, so it still counts. If you remember last year's ROG Phone 5 Pro didn't do so well during the durability test. So we'll have to see how well this newer version holds up because seeing a phone that expensive snap in half is very painful, even to me. You know what else is getting expensive? Phone service. Huge thanks to Tello for sponsoring this video. For 6 years now Tello has been offering the same wireless service as the big boys for half the price. For just $29 a month Tello has 4G, 5G, free hotspot, and free international calling to over 60 different countries, with no contracts and you can upgrade or downgrade your plan at any time. You don't need to take my word for it though, Tello has over 8,000 five star reviews. I think people are just excited that they can keep their same phone number and same phone when they switch over. Saving a ton of money on a new plan is always fun. You can always buy a new phone if you switch, if your old phone is starting to look like the ROG Phone 5 from the last durability test, and you can mix and match plans from their cheapest down at $5 a month, all the way up to the unlimited at $29. You can add up to 10 lines on a family plan, getting premium service without the premium price tag. Just head to the link down in the description, pick a plan, and pop the SIM card into your existing phone and you're done. Easy, all with no contracts, and they even do the e-sim thing if you're into that. Link is down in the description, and huge thanks to Tello for sponsoring this video. Now it's time to see if the Republic of Gamers, this ROG Phone 6 Pro, has made any improvements from last year. Let's get started. [Intro] The ROG Phone 6 Pro is definitely the most powerful smartphone we've tested this year. And definitely the most expensive....and also has the most complicated box to open. I really am struggling with this one, and I'm kind of an expert at opening phone boxes. Ah, you can't hold the box while you're opening it. Squeezing the sides won't let it slide. Big brain time. Off to a good start. Inside the hexagonal carton we have an AR card for some virtual reality gaming stuff that ROG does. We also have the phone itself. Super heavy in its plastic sleeve. Underneath the phone we find a thin flexible rubber case, which won't be much help structurally, but would help with impacts and scratches. I'll set this off to the side. We also have the massive 65 watt USB-C charging brick, which powers the dual batteries inside of the ROG 6. There's also a pretty classy USB-C braided cable which is kind of cool. The box is intense, but the phone is also intense. Speaking of which, let's get a closer look at the ROG 6 Pro, and compare it to the ROG 5 from last year and see if ASUS has changed anything. [Music playing] The 6 starts playing walkout music like this is some kind of boxing match. On the sides of the phone we have the same antenna line placement between both generations, the same power button locations, and same charging port locations, with the only difference being little gold contacts on the side of the 5. For the most part, this busted 5 and the new 6 look structurally identical. [Music playing] So as far as having a phone in one piece after this test is over. I won't be holding my breath. Mostly because this video would be awfully quiet if I did. Let's see what else the ROG 6 Pro has to offer besides invigorating smartphone setup music. The design at first feels pretty solid. In years past, ROG has iconically been the phone with the metal hump and vents out the back glass for cooling. This year they've done away with the vents in exchange for a pretty cool back display. It can show notifications and charging status among other things. I mean, personally I think more RGBs would have been cool, but I'm all for the creativeness that goes into gaming phones. There are dual USB-C ports as you can tell so you can charge the phone horizontally while gaming, as well as add plug-in accessories, like the aerial active thermoelectric cooler that's like a portable refrigerator for your phone. A cool accessory to be sure. Let's begin the scratch test...After removing the pre-installed screen protector, of course. This standardized scratch test can find out what the screen is made from. At $1300 it could very well be sapphire. But as we work our way up through Mohs scale of hardness past level 2 where we would see plastic start to scratch, and beyond level 5, we do start seeing scratches at a level 6 with deeper grooves at a level 7. The ROG 6 Pro is using Gorilla Glass Victis, at least on the front. This means that the 12 megapixel selfie camera tucked up into the top bezel is also protected by that same glass. Between the glass and the frame we have a super thin and deep earpiece slit that doubles as one of the symmetrical loudspeakers. There is an equally sized slit at the bottom. No grill or anything else that would fall out. The sides of the ROG 6 Pro near the gaming triggers are made from anodized aluminum, and surprisingly the buttons are removable. We have the smaller metal power button with a blue accent, and the larger volume rocker that can also pop out of the phone like we've seen on Samsung devices. So be careful if you have the type of friends who would steal your buttons. Also if you have the type of friends who would steal your buttons, you need new friends. The top of the phone has nothing...just like Ye after last week. And here on the left side we have again the accessory USB-C port which can also fully charge the dual batteries at a whopping 65 watts. The cute little blue SIM card tray once again does not have a rubber ring around the opening. The 6 Pro is ipx4, meaning that it can handle a bit of a splash or a sprinkle of liquid, but no submersions. If we look really close, closer than we've ever looked at a SIM card tray before, we do see the tiniest of little rubber lips, which is probably to help keep the SIM card tray in place. Down here at the bottom we have another 65 watt USB-C port. Only one can be used to charge the phone at a time. We also have a headphone jack which is pretty rare these days. One thing I can definitely appreciate with the ROG6 Pro is the attention to detail and the refreshingly unique design. For example, just beyond the secondary 2 inch screen we have embossed text. Instead of using a sticker inlaying or engraving, ROG has raised letters on the glass. It's subtle but satisfyingly different. It's hard to read the clear on white text, but it says 'Join the Republic.' Republic is the R in ROG. Moving our way up to the camera bump, we have our 50 megapixel main camera, 13 megapixel ultra wide, and a 5 megapixel macro camera, all protected by glass with a singular flash off to the side. Enclosed in an ever so slightly protruding camera bump. So far I'm a pretty big fan of the ROG 6 Pro. The 6.8 inch 1080p screen takes visualization to another level with 1 billion colors, 165 hertz refresh rate, and from the looks of it, the display lasts about 30 seconds under the heat from my lighter before burning black and not recovering. It's AMOLED. Last year the fingerprint scanner struggled with my fingerprint. And for some reason most phones do. This ROG 6 Pro is no different. It thinks my thumbprint is dirty even though it's not. It'll be nice when the underscreen technology improves enough to function with people who work with their hands. Once it was set, and then damaged with some level 7 deeper grooves, the scanner does continue to function just fine though, even with the extra scratches. There's a shortage of perfect phones in the world and it would be a pity to damage this one. Historically, most phones do survive my durability tests, but at first glance, since ROG hasn't changed anything structurally from last year's catastrophe, I don't have high hopes for this year. I guess if nothing changes...then nothing changes. The ROG Phone 6 Pro fails my durability test catastrophically again. That's two years in a row now. The front glass of the phone, while majorly curved and not functional anymore, doesn't appear to be cracked. The back glass however, is obliterated with just the foil barely holding the glass shards together. We'll have to dive deeper into the structure during the teardown, but at first glance it looks like the bend test happened between the two batteries again just like last year, along that metal motherboard and at that centrally placed power button and side USB-C port on each of the frame rails. Crazy enough the rear screen does appear to still be lit and functional under the obliteration, so thumbs up for that. Super impressive rear screen there ROG. The front screen has no surface level cracks, nice work Victus, but the screen under the protective top glass is cracked and won't be functioning again. Hopefully ROG is already working on a solution for next year since, in my opinion, the world's most powerful smartphone should also be able to handle the physical world as well as the digital world. And, of course, I'll be right here to keep you updated on if anything changes. Hit that subscribe button if you haven't already. Let me know your thoughts down in the comments, and come hang out with me on Instagram. Thanks a ton for watching. I'll see you around.
